items.title: Interstellar comet's alien dust unlike anything in our solar system

featured_image.name: Comet 3I/ATLAS is back, and brand new images show its tail is ...

items.description:
The interstellar visitor 3I/ATLAS continues to defy expectations, maintaining active outgassing and shedding material with a chemical composition unlike anything found in our solar system—even as it recedes toward the outer reaches of space.

A ground-based telescope in Hawaii captured the object on January 14, 2026, revealing a compact nucleus surrounded by a structured coma and the early formation of a tail, despite the comet being approximately 300 million kilometers from Earth. At such distances, most small bodies would fade into obscurity, yet 3I/ATLAS remains visible and active.[1][2]

items.title: Zelensky rejects Trump's claim that Ukraine is blocking peace

featured_image.name: Trump says Zelensky is holding up peace deal

items.description:
Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy firmly rejected U.S. President Donald Trump's assertion that Ukraine is obstructing peace negotiations, declaring that his country "has never been and will never be an obstacle to peace" while pointing to ongoing Russian attacks on civilian infrastructure as evidence of Moscow's true intentions.

The dispute erupted after Trump told Reuters on January 15 that Russian President Vladimir Putin is "ready to make a deal" while characterizing Ukraine as "less ready." When asked why U.S.-led negotiations had failed to end the nearly four-year-old conflict, Trump responded with a single word: "Zelenskyy."[1][2][3]

items.title: US and Taiwan reach trade deal cutting tariffs, securing chip investment

featured_image.name: TSMC, the Chip Giant, Is to Spend $100 Billion in U.S. Over the Next ...

items.description:
The United States and Taiwan have reached a trade agreement that will reduce tariffs on Taiwanese goods from 20 percent to 15 percent and secure hundreds of billions of dollars in semiconductor investment commitments, according to officials familiar with the matter. The deal, which the White House was set to announce Thursday, places Taiwan on equal footing with Japan and South Korea, which secured similar arrangements last year.[1][2]

Under the agreement, Taiwanese semiconductor companies will commit to a $500 billion increase in financing for American operations, with Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. pledging to build at least five additional fabrication plants in Arizona, effectively doubling its manufacturing presence in the state.[2][3][1]

items.title: Trump threatens tariffs on nations opposing his Greenland bid

featured_image.name: Denmark and Greenland say “fundamental disagreement” remains ...

items.description:
President Donald Trump warned Friday that he may impose tariffs on countries that do not support his efforts to acquire Greenland, escalating his campaign to take control of the strategically vital Arctic territory despite growing international opposition.

"I may put a tariff on countries if they don't go along with Greenland, because we need Greenland for national security," Trump said during a roundtable event at the White House. The threat came as European nations deployed military personnel to the semiautonomous Danish territory for joint exercises, and a bipartisan delegation of U.S. lawmakers arrived in Copenhagen to demonstrate solidarity with Denmark.[1][2][3]

items.title: Former South Korean president sentenced to 5 years in prison

featured_image.name: Court orders South Korean President Yoon released from jail ...

items.description:
Former South Korean President Yoon Suk Yeol was sentenced to five years in prison on Friday by the Seoul Central District Court, marking the first verdict in a series of criminal trials stemming from his brief declaration of martial law in December 2024.[1][2][3]

The court found Yoon guilty of obstructing authorities from executing an arrest warrant, falsifying official documents, and failing to follow proper legal procedures for declaring martial law, according to a live broadcast of the verdict. The ruling comes half the 10-year sentence prosecutors had requested, setting the stage for a more consequential insurrection verdict expected next month.[4][3]

items.title: Canada and China strike trade deal on EVs, canola amid US tensions

featured_image.name: Canada's Carney hails ‘strategic partnership' in talks with China's Xi

items.description:
Canadian Prime Minister Mark Carney and Chinese President Xi Jinping announced a landmark trade agreement on Friday in Beijing, with Canada agreeing to slash tariffs on Chinese electric vehicles in exchange for China reducing duties on Canadian agricultural products, marking a dramatic shift in Ottawa's trade policy away from the United States.

Under the deal, Canada will allow up to 49,000 Chinese EVs into the country at a 6.1% tariff rate, replacing the 100% duty imposed by former Prime Minister Justin Trudeau in 2024. The quota will increase to 70,000 vehicles over five years. In return, China will lower tariffs on Canadian canola seed from approximately 84% to 15% by March 1, according to statements from both governments.[1][2][3][4][5][6]

items.title: Interstellar comet 3I/ATLAS makes final pass before leaving solar system

featured_image.name: Interstellar comet 3I/ATLAS shines in new image captured ...

items.description: The interstellar comet 3I/ATLAS, only the third object from beyond our solar system ever detected passing through our cosmic neighborhood, is making its final observable appearance before vanishing into the void. The Virtual Telescope Project is hosting a farewell livestream today at 21:00 UTC to mark humanity's last opportunity to view the celestial visitor.[1][2]

items.title: Interstellar comet 3I/ATLAS spins every 7 hours, study finds

featured_image.name: 3I/ATLAS rotation explained: Why this interstellar object spins every 7.1 hours?

items.description:
The interstellar comet 3I/ATLAS completes a full rotation approximately every 7.1 hours, according to new research by Harvard astrophysicist Abraham Loeb and Italian astronomer Toni Scarmato. The findings arrive just days before a rare celestial alignment on January 22 that could provide unprecedented data about this cosmic traveler from beyond our solar system.

The study, which analyzed Hubble Space Telescope images from late 2025, used two independent methods to determine the rotation period: tracking the wobble of the comet's jet-like features and measuring brightness variations over time. The jet position angle analysis yielded a period of 7.20 ± 0.05 hours, while photometric measurements produced 7.136 ± 0.001 hours.[1][2][3]

items.title: China's giant telescope captures first clear evidence of fast radio burst origins

featured_image.name: China's FAST telescope discovered over 740 new pulsars ...

items.description:
Using the world's largest single-dish radio telescope, an international team of researchers has captured the first clear evidence linking mysterious cosmic radio signals to a dense plasma cloud, providing strong support for the theory that some fast radio bursts originate from binary star systems.

The findings, published Friday in the journal Science, are based on nearly 20 months of observations by China's Five-hundred-meter Aperture Spherical radio Telescope, known as FAST, of a repeating fast radio burst designated FRB 20220529, located approximately 2.9 billion light-years from Earth.[1][2][3]

items.title: Astronomers discover massive iron bar hiding inside Ring Nebula

featured_image.name: Webb telescope captures stunning new look at the Ring Nebula ...

items.description:
A European team has discovered a hidden bar of iron stretching across the interior of the Ring Nebula, one of the most iconic objects in the night sky. The structure, described for the first time this week in Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society, contains a mass of iron atoms comparable to Mars and had gone completely unnoticed despite decades of observations.[1][2][3]

The discovery raises a puzzle that astronomers cannot yet solve: how did such a large concentration of iron end up in such a distinct shape inside a nebula formed from a dying star?

items.title: Taiwan shares surge to record after US finalizes trade deal

featured_image.name: US and Taiwan reach trade deal, with semiconductor chips and China in focus

items.description:
Asian markets finished Friday with divergent outcomes as Taiwan led regional gains, surging nearly 2 percent to a record close after the United States and Taiwan finalized a semiconductor-focused trade agreement the day before.

The Taiwan Weighted Index climbed 1.94 percent to close at a record 31,408.7, making it the best-performing Asian market on Friday. The rally came after Washington and Taipei announced a deal on Thursday that will reduce tariffs on Taiwanese goods from 20 percent to 15 percent while securing commitments from Taiwanese chip and technology companies to invest at least $250 billion in U.S. production capacity.[1][2][3]

items.title: Silver coating makes solid-state batteries 5 times crack-resistant

featured_image.name: Ford Partner SK On Achieves Solid State Battery Breakthrough

items.description:
A team of Stanford researchers has discovered that applying an ultrathin coating of silver to solid electrolytes makes them nearly five times more resistant to cracking, addressing one of the most persistent obstacles to commercializing next-generation lithium metal batteries.

The findings, published January 16 in Nature Materials, could accelerate development of batteries that are safer, store more energy, and charge faster than today's lithium-ion technology.[1][2]

items.title: UN High Seas Treaty to take effect, protecting two-thirds of ocean

featured_image.name: Protecting the High Seas: Ensuring Strong, Effective MPAs Under ...

items.description:
The United Nations High Seas Treaty, formally known as the Biodiversity Beyond National Jurisdiction (BBNJ) Agreement, will officially enter into force on January 17, 2026, establishing the first legally binding international framework to protect marine biodiversity in nearly two-thirds of the world's ocean.[1][2][3]

The treaty becomes international law after Morocco became the 60th nation to ratify it on September 19, 2025, triggering a 120-day countdown to implementation. Currently, 82 countries have officially joined the agreement, and 145 of the UN's 193 member states have signed it.[2][4][5][1]

items.title: MIT team cools trapped ions 10 times below standard limit

featured_image.name: Ion traps – DLR Quantum Computing Initiative

items.description:
Two separate research efforts published this week are advancing the frontiers of quantum computing by solving distinct challenges: achieving efficient cooling for chip-based systems and discovering unexpected quantum states in exotic materials.

Researchers at MIT and MIT Lincoln Laboratory announced Wednesday a technique for cooling trapped ions using integrated photonics that reaches temperatures about 10 times below the standard laser cooling limit, known as the Doppler limit. The method achieves this in approximately 100 microseconds, several times faster than existing approaches.[1][2][3]

Meanwhile, scientists at TU Wien in Vienna and Rice University revealed Tuesday in Nature Physics that they observed an "emergent topological semimetal" — a quantum state previously considered impossible because it combines two phenomena thought to be incompatible.[4][5][6]

items.title: Venezuela's acting president calls for oil reforms, US thaw

featured_image.name: Venezuela's Rodriguez proposes oil reform to ease investment

items.description:
Less than two weeks after the United States military captured Nicolás Maduro, Venezuela's acting president used her first major address to lawmakers to call for sweeping reforms to the country's oil industry and a diplomatic thaw with Washington.

In a 44-minute state of the union speech on Thursday, Delcy Rodríguez urged Venezuela's National Assembly to approve changes to the nation's hydrocarbon law that would open doors to greater foreign investment in the state-controlled oil sector. The address marked a striking departure from the anti-American rhetoric that defined her predecessor's rule.[1][2]

items.title: Israeli startup nT-Tao fires first plasma in compact fusion reactor

featured_image.name: Israeli nuclear fusion firm fires first plasma in two months toward 20 ...

items.description:
Israeli compact fusion energy company nT-Tao announced on January 15, 2026 that its C3 prototype has successfully fired its first plasma pulses, reaching operational status just over two months after assembly began. The milestone represents a concrete advancement in the company's pursuit of a container-sized fusion reactor capable of generating 10-20 MW of clean power.[1][2]

The Hod Hasharon-based startup's C3 system builds directly upon the successful experimental campaign of its predecessor, the C2-A, which achieved plasma temperatures of approximately one million degrees Celsius—roughly 100 electron volts—at the intended high-density regime. The new prototype incorporates design refinements across magnets, pulsed power systems, diagnostics, and overall integration, with experimental goals focused on reaching higher temperatures and extended confinement durations.[3][2][4]

items.title: Einstein's wormholes may be time bridges, not space tunnels

featured_image.name: Wormholes may not exist – we've found they reveal something ...

items.description:
Wormholes, long imagined as cosmic tunnels for interstellar travel and time machines, may not exist as shortcuts through space at all. Instead, new research suggests that Einstein-Rosen bridges—the mathematical structures behind the wormhole concept—represent something more fundamental: connections between two opposing directions of time.

A paper published this week in the journal Classical and Quantum Gravity by astrophysicist Enrique Gaztañaga and colleagues presents a reinterpretation of the original 1935 work by Albert Einstein and Nathan Rosen. The researchers argue that the popular conception of wormholes arose from a misunderstanding of what the physicists intended.[1][2]

items.title: Trump announces 'Board of Peace' to oversee Gaza governance

featured_image.name: Trump says he plans to name Gaza Board of Peace early next ...

items.description:
President Donald Trump announced Thursday that the "Board of Peace" for Gaza has been officially formed, moving forward with the second phase of his 20-point plan to end the conflict in the Palestinian territory. The announcement came via his Truth Social platform, one day after his special envoy Steve Witkoff declared the launch of the plan's next stage.[1][2][3]

"It is my Great Honor to announce that THE BOARD OF PEACE has been formed," Trump wrote, adding that the body's members would be revealed "shortly." He called it "the Greatest and Most Prestigious Board ever assembled at any time, any place."[4][5]

items.title: Chinese universities claim 8 of top 10 spots in global research rankings

featured_image.name: China's expanding role in global higher education rankings ...

items.description:
Zhejiang University has claimed the top spot in the Leiden Rankings, a global measure of research productivity, pushing Harvard to third place and marking a shift in academic power that reflects both China's strategic investments in science and the mounting financial pressures facing American higher education.

The rankings, produced by the Centre for Science and Technology Studies at Leiden University in the Netherlands, now feature eight Chinese institutions in the top 10. Twenty years ago, only one Chinese school would have made the top 25.[1][2][3]

items.title: Scientists map hidden landscape beneath Antarctica's ice

featured_image.name: New map of Antarctica reveals hidden world of lakes, valleys ...

items.description:
A team of international scientists has produced the most comprehensive map yet of Antarctica's concealed terrain, revealing thousands of previously unknown hills, ridges, and river channels buried beneath miles of ice. The breakthrough, published Thursday in the journal Science, could transform researchers' ability to predict how the frozen continent will respond to climate change and contribute to rising sea levels.[1][2][3]

The map uncovers geological features spanning 2 to 30 kilometers beneath the ice sheet, which covers more than 5.4 million square miles. Among the discoveries are deep alpine valleys, extensive channels carved by ancient flowing water that stretch for hundreds of kilometers, and sharp transitions between highland and lowland terrain that may indicate tectonic boundaries.[4][3][1]
